Eknath Easwaran: ARJUNA:  O Krishna, you have said that knowledge is greater than action; why then do you ask me to wage this terrible war?
Mahatma Gandhi: If, O Krishna, you hold that the attitude of detachment is superior to  action, then why, O Krishna, do you urge me to dreadful action?
Shri Swami Purohit: “Arjuna questioned: My Lord! If Wisdom is above action, why do You advise me to engage in this terrible fight?

Eknath Easwaran: Your advice seems inconsistent. Give me one path to follow to the supreme good.
Mahatma Gandhi: You do seem to confuse my understanding with perplexing speech; tell  me, therefore, in no uncertain voice, that alone whereby I may attain salvation.   The Lord Said:
Shri Swami Purohit: Your language perplexes me and confuses my reason. Therefore please tell me the only way by which I may, without doubt, secure my spiritual welfare.

Eknath Easwaran: KRISHNA:  At the beginning of time I declared two paths for the pure heart: jnana yoga, the contemplative path of spiritual wisdom, and karma yoga, the active path of selfless service.
Mahatma Gandhi: I have spoken, before, O sinless one, of two attitudes in this world—the  Sankhayas', that of Jnana yoga and the Yogins', that of karma yoga.
Shri Swami Purohit: Lord Shri Krishna replied: In this world, as I have said, there is a twofold path, O Sinless One! There is the Path of Wisdom for those who meditate, and the Path of Action for those who work.

Eknath Easwaran: One who shirks action does not attain freedom; no one can gain perfection by abstaining from work.
Mahatma Gandhi: Never does man enjoy freedom from action by not undertaking action, nor  does he attain that freedom by mere renunciation of action.
Shri Swami Purohit: No man can attain freedom from activity by refraining from action; nor can he reach perfection by merely refusing to act.

Eknath Easwaran: Indeed, there is no one who rests for even an instant; all creatures are driven to action by their own nature.
Mahatma Gandhi: For none ever remains inactive even for a moment; for all are compelled to  action by the gunas inherent in prakriti.
Shri Swami Purohit: He cannot even for a moment remain really inactive, for the Qualities of Nature will compel him to act whether he will or no.

Eknath Easwaran: Those who abstain from action while allowing the mind to dwell on sensual pleasure cannot be called sincere spiritual aspirants.
Mahatma Gandhi: He who curbs the organs of action but allows the mind to dwell on the  sense-objects,—such a one, wholly deluded, is called a hypocrite.
Shri Swami Purohit: He who remains motionless, refusing to act, but all the while brooding over sensuous object, that deluded soul is simply a hypocrite.

Eknath Easwaran: But they excel who control their senses through the mind, using them for selfless service.
Mahatma Gandhi: But he, O Arjuna, who keeping all the senses under control of the mind,  engages the organs in Karma yoga, without attachment—that man excels.
Shri Swami Purohit: But, O Arjuna! All honour to him whose mind controls his senses, for he is thereby beginning to practise Karma-Yoga, the Path of Right Action, keeping himself always unattached.

Eknath Easwaran: Fulfill all your duties; action is better than inaction. Even to maintain your body, Arjuna, you are obliged to act.
Mahatma Gandhi: Do you your allotted task; for action is superior to inaction; with inaction even  life's normal course is not possible.
Shri Swami Purohit: Do your duty as prescribed, for action for duty’s sake is superior to inaction. Even the maintenance of the body would be impossible if man remained inactive.

Eknath Easwaran: Selfish action imprisons the world. Act selflessly, without any thought of personal profit.
Mahatma Gandhi: This world of men suffers bondage from all action save that which is done for  the sake of sacrifice; to this end, O Arjuna, perform action without  attachment.
Shri Swami Purohit: In this world people are fettered by action, unless it is performed as a sacrifice. Therefore, O Arjuna, let your acts be done without attachment, as sacrifice only.

Eknath Easwaran: At the beginning, mankind and the obligation of selfless service were created together. Through selfless service, you will always be fruitful and find the fulfillment of your desires: this is the promise of the Creator.
Mahatma Gandhi: Together with sacrifice did the Lord of beings create, of old, mankind,  declaring:  "By this shall you increase; may this be to you the giver of all your desires.
Shri Swami Purohit: In the beginning, when God created all beings by the sacrifice of Himself, He said unto them: `Through sacrifice you can procreate, and it shall satisfy all your desires.

Eknath Easwaran: Honor and cherish the devas as they honor and cherish you; through this honor and love you will attain the supreme good.
Mahatma Gandhi: "With this may you cherish the gods and may the gods cherish you; thus  cherishing one another may you attain the highest good.
Shri Swami Purohit: Worship the Powers of Nature thereby, and let them nourish you in return; thus supporting each other, you shall attain your highest welfare.

Eknath Easwaran: All human desires are fulfilled by the devas, who are pleased by selfless service. But anyone who enjoys the things given by the devas without offering selfless acts in return is a thief.
Mahatma Gandhi: "Cherished with sacrifice, the gods will bestow on you the desired boons."  He who enjoys their gifts without rendering aught unto them is verily a thief.
Shri Swami Purohit: For, fed, on sacrifice, nature will give you all the enjoyment you can desire. But he who enjoys what she gives without returning is, indeed, a robber.’

Eknath Easwaran: The spiritually minded, who eat in the spirit of service, are freed from all their sins; but the selfish, who prepare food for their own satisfaction, eat sin.
Mahatma Gandhi: The righteous men who eat the residue of the sacrifice are freed from all sin,  but the wicked who cook for themselves eat sin.
Shri Swami Purohit: The sages who enjoy the food that remains after the sacrifice is made are freed from all sin; but the selfish who spread their feast only for themselves feed on sin only.

Eknath Easwaran: Living creatures are nourished by food, and food is nourished by rain; rain itself is the water of life, which comes from selfless worship and service.
Mahatma Gandhi: From food springs all life, from rain is born food; from sacrifice comes rain  and sacrifice is the result of action.
Shri Swami Purohit: All creatures are the product of food, food is the product of rain, rain comes by sacrifice, and sacrifice is the noblest form of action.

Eknath Easwaran: Every selfless act, Arjuna, is born from Brahman, the eternal, infinite Godhead. Brahman is present in every act of service.
Mahatma Gandhi: Know that action springs from Brahman and Brahman from the  Imperishable; hence the all-pervading Brahman is ever firm-founded on  sacrifice.
Shri Swami Purohit: All action originates in the Supreme Spirit, which is Imperishable, and in sacrificial action the all-pervading Spirit is consciously present.

Eknath Easwaran: All life turns on this law, O Arjuna. Those who violate it, indulging the senses for their own pleasure and ignoring the needs of others, have wasted their life.
Mahatma Gandhi: He who does not follow the wheel thus set in motion here below, he, living  in sin, sating his senses, lives, O Arjuna, in vain.
Shri Swami Purohit: Thus he who does not help the revolving wheel of sacrifice, but instead leads a sinful life, rejoicing in the gratification of his senses, O Arjuna, he breathes in vain.

Eknath Easwaran: But those who realize the Self are always satisfied. Having found the source of joy and fulfillment, they no longer seek happiness from the external world.
Mahatma Gandhi: But the man who revels in soul, who is content in soul and who is  satisfied only with soul, for him no action exists.
Shri Swami Purohit: On the other hand, the soul who meditates on the Self is content to serve the Self and rests satisfied within the Self; there remains nothing more for him to accomplish.

Eknath Easwaran: They have nothing to gain or lose by any action; neither people nor things can affect their security.
Mahatma Gandhi: He has no interest whatever in anything done, nor in anything not done, nor  has he need to rely on anything for personal ends.
Shri Swami Purohit: He has nothing to gain by the performance or non-performance of action. His welfare depends not on any contribution that an earthly creature can make.

Eknath Easwaran: Strive constantly to serve the welfare of the world; by devotion to selfless work one attains the supreme goal of life.
Mahatma Gandhi: Therefore, do you ever perform without attachment the work that you  must do; for performing action without attachment man attains the Supreme.
Shri Swami Purohit: Therefore do your duty perfectly, without care for the results, for he who does his duty disinterestedly attains the Supreme.

Eknath Easwaran: Do your work with the welfare of others always in mind. It was by such work that Janaka attained perfection; others too have followed this path.
Mahatma Gandhi: For through action alone Janaka and others achieved perfection; even with a  view to the guidance of mankind you must act.
Shri Swami Purohit: King Janaka and others attained perfection through action alone. Even for the sake of enlightening the world, it is your duty to act;

Eknath Easwaran: What the outstanding person does, others will try to do. The standards such people create will be followed by the whole world.
Mahatma Gandhi: Whatever the best man does, is also done by other men, what example he  sets, the world follows.
Shri Swami Purohit: For whatever a great man does, others imitate. People conform to the standard which he has set.

Eknath Easwaran: There is nothing in the three worlds for me to gain, Arjuna, nor is there anything I do not have; I continue to act, but I am not driven by any need of my own.
Mahatma Gandhi: For me, O Arjuna, there is nothing to do in the three worlds, nothing worth  gaining that I have not gained; yet I am ever in action.
Shri Swami Purohit: There is nothing in this universe, O Arjuna, that I am compelled to do, nor anything for Me to attain; yet I am persistently active.

Eknath Easwaran: If I ever refrained from continuous work, everyone would immediately follow my example.
Mahatma Gandhi: Indeed, for were I not, unslumbering, ever to remain in action, O Arjuna,  men would follow my example in every way.
Shri Swami Purohit: For were I not to act without ceasing, O prince, people would be glad to do likewise.

Eknath Easwaran: If I stopped working I would be the cause of cosmic chaos, and finally of the destruction of this world and these people.
Mahatma Gandhi: If I were not to perform my task, these worlds would be ruined; I should be  the same cause of chaos and of the end of all mankind.
Shri Swami Purohit: And if I were to refrain from action, the human race would be ruined; I should lead the world to chaos, and destruction would follow.

Eknath Easwaran: The ignorant work for their own profit, Arjuna; the wise work for the welfare of the world, without thought for themselves.
Mahatma Gandhi: Just as, with attachment, the unenlightened perform all actions, O Arjuna,  even so, but unattached, should the enlightened man act, with a desire for the  welfare of humanity.
Shri Swami Purohit: As the ignorant act, because of their fondness for action, so should the wise act without such attachment, fixing their eyes, O Arjuna, only on the welfare of the world.

Eknath Easwaran: By abstaining from work you will confuse the ignorant, who are engrossed in their actions. Perform all work carefully, guided by compassion.
Mahatma Gandhi: The enlightened may not confuse the mind of the unenlightened, who are  attached to action; rather must he perform all actions unattached, and thus  encourage them to do likewise.
Shri Swami Purohit: But a wise man should not perturb the minds of the ignorant, who are attached to action; let him perform his own actions in the right spirit, with concentration on Me, thus inspiring all to do the same.

Eknath Easwaran: All actions are performed by the gunas of prakriti. Deluded by identification with the ego, a person thinks, I am the doer.
Mahatma Gandhi: All action is entirely done by the gunas of prakriti. Man, deluded by the  sense of ‘I', thinks, ‘I am the doer'.
Shri Swami Purohit: Action is the product of the Qualities inherent in Nature. It is only the ignorant man who, misled by personal egotism, says: `I am the doer.’

Eknath Easwaran: But the illumined man or woman understands the domain of the gunas and is not attached. Such people know that the gunas interact with each other; they do not claim to be the doer.
Mahatma Gandhi: But he, O Arjuna, who understands the truth of the various gunas and  their various activities, knows that it is the gunas that operate on the gunas; he  does not claim to be the doer.
Shri Swami Purohit: But he, O Mighty One, who understands correctly the relation of the Qualities to action, is not attached to the act for he perceives that it is merely the action and reaction of the Qualities among themselves.

Eknath Easwaran: Those who are deluded by the operation of the gunas become attached to the results of their action. Those who understand these truths should not unsettle the ignorant.
Mahatma Gandhi: Deluded by the gunas of prakriti men become attached to the activities of  the gunas; he who knows the truth of things should not unhinge the  slow-witted who have not the knowledge.
Shri Swami Purohit: Those who do not understand the Qualities are interested in the act. Still, the wise man who knows the truth should not disturb the mind of him who does not.

Eknath Easwaran: Performing all actions for my sake, completely absorbed in the Self, and without expectations, fight!  but stay free from the fever of the ego.
Mahatma Gandhi: Cast all your acts on Me, with your mind fixed on the indwelling soul, and  without any thought of fruit, or sense of ‘mine' shake off your fever and fight!
Shri Swami Purohit: Therefore, surrendering your actions unto Me, your thoughts concentrated on the Absolute, free from selfishness and without anticipation of reward, with mind devoid of excitement, begin you to fight.

Eknath Easwaran: Those who live in accordance with these divine laws without complaining, firmly established in faith, are released from karma.
Mahatma Gandhi: Those who always act according to the rule I have here laid down, in faith  and without cavilling—they too are released from the bondage of their actions.
Shri Swami Purohit: Those who always act in accordance with My precepts, firm in faith and without cavilling, they too are freed from the bondage of action.

Eknath Easwaran: Those who violate these laws, criticizing and complaining, are utterly deluded, and are the cause of their own suffering.
Mahatma Gandhi: But those who cavil at the rule and refuse to conform to it are fools, dead to  all knowledge; know that they are lost.
Shri Swami Purohit: But they who ridicule My word and do not keep it, are ignorant, devoid of wisdom and blind. They seek but their own destruction.

Eknath Easwaran: Even the wise act within the limitations of their own nature. Every creature is subject to prakriti; what is the use of repression?
Mahatma Gandhi: Even a man of knowledge acts according to his nature; all creatures follow  their nature; what then will constraint avail?
Shri Swami Purohit: Even the wise man acts in character with his nature; indeed, all creatures act according to their natures. What is the use of compulsion then?

Eknath Easwaran: The senses have been conditioned by attraction to the pleasant and aversion to the unpleasant. Do not be ruled by them; they are obstacles in your path.
Mahatma Gandhi: Each sense has its settled likes and dislikes towards its objects; man should  not come under the sway of these, for they are his besetters.
Shri Swami Purohit: The love and hate which are aroused by the objects of sense arise from Nature; do not yield to them. They only obstruct the path.

Eknath Easwaran: It is better to strive in ones own dharma than to succeed in the dharma of another. Nothing is ever lost in following ones own dharma, but competition in anothers dharma breeds fear and insecurity.
Mahatma Gandhi: Better one's own duty, bereft of merit, than another's well-performed; better  is death in the discharge of one's duty; another's duty is fraught with danger.   Arjuna Said:
Shri Swami Purohit: It is better to do yours own duty, however lacking in merit, than to do that of another, even though efficiently. It is better to die doing one’s own duty, for to do the duty of another is fraught with danger.

Eknath Easwaran: ARJUNA:  What is the force that binds us to selfish deeds, O Krishna? What power moves us, even against our will, as if forcing us?
Mahatma Gandhi: Then what impels man to sin, O Krishna, even against his will, as though  by force compelled?  The Lord Said:
Shri Swami Purohit: Arjuna asked: My Lord! Tell me, what is it that drives a man to sin, even against his will and as if by compulsion?

Eknath Easwaran: KRISHNA: It is selfish desire and anger, arising from the guna of rajas; these are the appetites and evils which threaten a person in this life.
Mahatma Gandhi: It is Lust, it is Wrath, born of the guna—Rajas. It is the arch-devourer, the  arch-sinner. Know this to be man's enemy here.
Shri Swami Purohit: Lord Shri Krishna: It is desire, it is aversion, born of passion. Desire consumes and corrupts everything. It is man’s greatest enemy.

Eknath Easwaran: Just as a fire is covered by smoke and a mirror is obscured by dust, just as the embryo rests deep within the womb, knowledge is hidden by selfish desire
Mahatma Gandhi: As fire is obscured by smoke, a mirror by dirt, and the embryo by the  amnion, so is knowledge obscured by this.
Shri Swami Purohit: As fire is shrouded in smoke, a mirror by dust and a child by the womb, so is the universe enveloped in desire.

Eknath Easwaran: hidden, Arjuna, by this unquenchable fire for self-satisfaction, the inveterate enemy of the wise.
Mahatma Gandhi: Knowledge is obscured, O Arjuna, by this eternal enemy of the wise man,  in the form of Lust, the insatiable fire.
Shri Swami Purohit: It is the wise man’s constant enemy; it tarnishes the face of wisdom. It is as insatiable as a flame of fire.

Eknath Easwaran: Selfish desire is found in the senses, mind, and intellect, misleading them and burying the understanding in delusion.
Mahatma Gandhi: The senses, the mind and the reason are said to be its great seat; by means of  these it obscures knowledge and stupefies man.
Shri Swami Purohit: It works through the senses, the mind and the reason; and with their help destroys wisdom and confounds the soul.

Eknath Easwaran: Fight with all your strength, Arjuna! Controlling your senses, conquer your enemy, the destroyer of knowledge and realization.
Mahatma Gandhi: Therefore, O Arjuna, bridle you first the senses and then rid yourself  of this sinner, the destroyer of knowledge and discrimination.
Shri Swami Purohit: Therefore, O Arjuna, first control your senses and then slay desire, for it is full of sin, and is the destroyer of knowledge and of wisdom.

Eknath Easwaran: The senses are higher than the body, the mind higher than the senses; above the mind is the intellect, and above the intellect is the Atman.
Mahatma Gandhi: Subtle, they say, are the senses; subtler than the senses is the mind; subtler  than the mind is the reason; but subtler even than the reason is He.
Shri Swami Purohit: It is said that the senses are powerful. But beyond the senses is the mind, beyond the mind is the intellect, and beyond and greater than intellect is He.

Eknath Easwaran: Thus, knowing that which is supreme, let the Atman rule the ego. Use your mighty arms to slay the fierce enemy that is selfish desire.
Mahatma Gandhi: Thus realizing Him to be subtler than the reason, and controlling the self by  the Self (Atman), destroy, O Arjuna, this enemy—Lust, so hard to  overcome.
Shri Swami Purohit: Thus, O Mighty-in-Arms, knowing Him to be beyond the intellect and, by His help, subduing your personal egotism, kill yours enemy, Desire, extremely difficult though it be.”

Eknath Easwaran: ARJUNA:  O Krishna, you have recommended both the path of selfless action and sannyasa, the path of renunciation of action. Tell me definitely which is better.
Mahatma Gandhi: You laud renunciation of actions, O Krishna, whilst at the same time you  laud performance of action; tell me for a certainty which is the better.  The Lord Said:
Shri Swami Purohit: “Arjuna said: My Lord! At one moment You praise renunciation of action; at another, right action. Tell me truly, I pray, which of these is the more conducive to my highest welfare?

Eknath Easwaran: KRISHNA:  Both renunciation of action and the selfless performance of action lead to the supreme goal. But the path of action is better than renunciation.
Mahatma Gandhi: Renunciation and performance of action both lead to salvation; but of the  two, karmayoga (performance) is better than sannyasa (renunciation).
Shri Swami Purohit: Lord Shri Krishna replied: Renunciation of action and the path of right action both lead to the highest; of the two, right action is the better.

Eknath Easwaran: Those who have attained perfect renunciation are free from any sense of duality; they are unaffected by likes and dislikes, Arjuna, and are free from the bondage of self-will.
Mahatma Gandhi: Him one should know as ever renouncing who has no dislikes and likes; for  he who is free from the pairs of opposites is easily released from bondage.
Shri Swami Purohit: He is a true ascetic who never desires or dislikes, who is uninfluenced by the opposites and is easily freed from bondage.

Eknath Easwaran: The immature think that knowledge and action are different, but the wise see them as the same. The person who is established in one path will attain the rewards of both.
Mahatma Gandhi: It is the ignorant who speak of sankhya and yoga as different, not so those  who have knowledge. He who is rightly established even in one wins to the  fruit of both.
Shri Swami Purohit: Only the unenlightened speak of wisdom and right action as separate, not the wise. If any man knows one, he enjoys the fruit of both.

Eknath Easwaran: The goal of knowledge and the goal of service are the same; those who fail to see this are blind.
Mahatma Gandhi: The goal that the sankhyas attain is also reached by the yogins. He sees truly  who sees both sankhya and yoga as one.
Shri Swami Purohit: The level which is reached by wisdom is attained through right action as well. He who perceives that the two are one, knows the truth.

Eknath Easwaran: Perfect renunciation is difficult to attain without performing action. But the wise, following the path of selfless service, quickly reach Brahman.
Mahatma Gandhi: But renunciation, O Arjuna, is hard to attain except by yoga; the ascetic  equipped with yoga attains Brahman before long.
Shri Swami Purohit: Without concentration, O Mighty Man, renunciation is difficult. But the sage who is always meditating on the Divine, before long shall attain the Absolute.

Eknath Easwaran: Those who follow the path of service, who have completely purified themselves and conquered their senses and self-will, see the Self in all creatures and are untouched by any action they perform.
Mahatma Gandhi: The yogi who has cleared himself, has gained mastery over his mind and all  his senses, who has become one with the soul in all creation, although he acts  he remains unaffected.
Shri Swami Purohit: He who is spiritual, who is pure, who has overcome his senses and his personal self, who has realised his highest Self as the Self of all, such a one, even though he acts, is not bound by his acts.

Eknath Easwaran: Those who know this truth, whose consciousness is unified, think always, I am not the doer. While seeing or hearing, touching or smelling; eating, moving about, or sleeping; breathing
Mahatma Gandhi: The yogi who has seen the Truth knows that it is not he that acts whilst  seeing, hearing, touching, smelling, eating, walking, sleeping, or breathing,
Shri Swami Purohit: Though the saint sees, hears, touches, smells, eats, moves, sleeps and breathes, yet he knows the Truth, and he knows that it is not he who acts.

Eknath Easwaran: or speaking, letting go or holding on, even opening or closing the eyes, they understand that these are only the movements of the senses among sense objects.
Mahatma Gandhi: Talking, letting go, holding fast, opening or closing the eyes—in the  conviction that is the senses that are moving in their respective spheres.
Shri Swami Purohit: Though he talks, though he gives and receives, though he opens his eyes and shuts them, he still knows that his senses are merely disporting themselves among the objects of perception.

Eknath Easwaran: Those who surrender to Brahman all selfish attachments are like the leaf of a lotus floating clean and dry in water. Sin cannot touch them.
Mahatma Gandhi: He who dedicates his actions to Brahman and performs them without  attachment is not smeared by sin, as the lotus-leaf by water.
Shri Swami Purohit: He who dedicates his actions to the Spirit, without any personal attachment to them, he is no more tainted by sin than the water lily is wetted by water.

Eknath Easwaran: Renouncing their selfish attachments, those who follow the path of service work with body, senses, and mind for the sake of self-purification.
Mahatma Gandhi: Only with the body, mind and intellect and also with the senses, do the  yogins perform action without attachment for the sake of self-purification.
Shri Swami Purohit: The sage performs his action dispassionately, using his body, mind and intellect, and even his senses, always as a means of purification.

Eknath Easwaran: Those whose consciousness is unified abandon all attachment to the results of action and attain supreme peace. But those whose desires are fragmented, who are selfishly attached to the results of their work, are bound in everything they do.
Mahatma Gandhi: A man of yoga obtains everlasting peace by abandoning the fruit of action;  the man ignorant of yoga, selfishly attached to fruit, remains bound.
Shri Swami Purohit: Having abandoned the fruit of action, he wins eternal peace. Others unacquainted with spirituality, led by desire and clinging to the benefit which they think will follow their actions, become entangled in them.

Eknath Easwaran: Those who renounce attachment in all their deeds live content in the city of nine gates, the body, as its master. They are not driven to act, nor do they involve others in action.
Mahatma Gandhi: Renouncing with the mind all actions, the dweller in the body, who is  master of himself, rests happily in his city of nine gates, neither doing nor  getting anything done.
Shri Swami Purohit: Mentally renouncing all actions, the self-controlled soul enjoys bliss in this body, the city of the nine gates, neither doing anything himself nor causing anything to be done.

Eknath Easwaran: Neither the sense of acting, nor actions, nor the connection of cause and effect comes from the Lord of this world. These three arise from nature.
Mahatma Gandhi: The Lord creates neither agency nor action for the world; neither does he  connect action with its fruit. It is nature that is at work.
Shri Swami Purohit: The Lord of this universe has not ordained activity, or any incentive thereto, or any relation between an act and its consequences. All this is the work of Nature.

Eknath Easwaran: The Lord does not partake in the good and evil deeds of any person; judgment is clouded when wisdom is obscured by ignorance.
Mahatma Gandhi: The Lord does not take upon Himself anyone's vice or virtue; it is ignorance  that veils knowledge and deludes all creatures.
Shri Swami Purohit: The Lord does not accept responsibility for any man’s sin or merit. Men are deluded because in them wisdom is submerged in ignorance.

Eknath Easwaran: But ignorance is destroyed by knowledge of the Self within. The light of this knowledge shines like the sun, revealing the supreme Brahman.
Mahatma Gandhi: But to them whose ignorance is destroyed by the knowledge of soul, this  their knowledge, like the sun, reveals the Supreme.
Shri Swami Purohit: Surely wisdom is like the sun, revealing the supreme truth to those whose ignorance is dispelled by the wisdom of the Self.

Eknath Easwaran: Those who cast off sin through this knowledge, absorbed in the Lord and established in him as their one goal and refuge, are not reborn as separate creatures.
Mahatma Gandhi: Those whose intellect is suffused with That, whose self has become one with  That, who abide in That, and whose end and aim is that, wipe out their sins  with knowledge, and go where there is no return.
Shri Swami Purohit: Meditating on the Divine, having faith in the Divine, concentrating on the Divine and losing themselves in the Divine, their sins dissolved in wisdom, they go where there is no return.

Eknath Easwaran: Those who possess this wisdom have equal regard for all. They see the same Self in a spiritual aspirant and an outcaste, in an elephant, a cow, and a dog.
Mahatma Gandhi: The men of Self-realization look with an equal eye on a brahmana  possessed of learning and humility, a cow, an elephant, a dog and even a  dog-eater.
Shri Swami Purohit: Sages look equally upon all, whether he be a minister of learning and humility, or an infidel, or whether it be a cow, an elephant or a dog.

Eknath Easwaran: Such people have mastered life. With even mind they rest in Brahman, who is perfect and is everywhere the same.
Mahatma Gandhi: In this very body they have conquered the round of birth and death, whose  mind is anchored in sameness; for perfect Brahman is same to all, therefore in  Brahman they rest.
Shri Swami Purohit: Even in this world they conquer their earth-life whose minds, fixed on the Supreme, remain always balanced; for the Supreme has neither blemish nor bias.

Eknath Easwaran: They are not elated by good fortune nor depressed by bad. With mind established in Brahman, they are free from delusion.
Mahatma Gandhi: He whose understanding is secure, who is undeluded, who knows Brahman  and who rests in Brahman, will neither be glad to get what is pleasant, nor sad  to get what is unpleasant.
Shri Swami Purohit: He who knows and lives in the Absolute remains unmoved and unperturbed; he is not elated by pleasure or depressed by pain.

Eknath Easwaran: Not dependent on any external support, they realize the joy of spiritual awareness. With consciousness unified through meditation, they live in abiding joy.
Mahatma Gandhi: He who has detached himself from contacts without, finds bliss in soul;  having achieved union with Brahman he enjoys eternal bliss.
Shri Swami Purohit: He finds happiness in his own Self, and enjoys eternal bliss, whose heart does not yearn for the contacts of earth and whose Self is one with the Everlasting.

Eknath Easwaran: Pleasures conceived in the world of the senses have a beginning and an end and give birth to misery, Arjuna. The wise do not look for happiness in them.
Mahatma Gandhi: For the joys derived from sense-contacts are nothing but mines of misery;  they have beginning and end, O Arjuna; the wise man does not revel therein.
Shri Swami Purohit: The joys that spring from external associations bring pain; they have their beginning and their endings. The wise man does not rejoice in them.

Eknath Easwaran: But those who overcome the impulses of lust and anger which arise in the body are made whole and live in joy.
Mahatma Gandhi: The man who is able even here on earth, before he is released from the body, to  hold out against the floodtide of lust and wrath,—he is a yogi, he is happy.
Shri Swami Purohit: He who, before he leaves his body, learns to surmount the promptings of desire and anger is a saint and is happy.

Eknath Easwaran: They find their joy, their rest, and their light completely within themselves. United with the Lord, they attain nirvana in Brahman.
Mahatma Gandhi: He who finds happiness only within, rest only within, light only  within,—that yogi, having become one with nature, attains to oneness with  Brahman.
Shri Swami Purohit: He who is happy within his Self and has found Its peace, and in whom the inner light shines, that sage attains Eternal Bliss and becomes the Spirit Itself.

Eknath Easwaran: Healed of their sins and conflicts, working for the good of all beings, the holy sages attain nirvana in Brahman.
Mahatma Gandhi: They win oneness with Brahman—the seers whose sins are wiped out,  whose doubts are resolved, who have mastered themselves, and who are  engrossed in the welfare of all beings.
Shri Swami Purohit: Sages whose sins have been washed away, whose sense of separateness has vanished, who have subdued themselves, and seek only the welfare of all, come to the Eternal Spirit.

Eknath Easwaran: Free from anger and selfish desire, unified in mind, those who follow the path of yoga and realize the Self are established forever in that supreme state.
Mahatma Gandhi: Rid of lust and wrath, masters of themselves, the ascetics who have realized  soul find oneness with Brahman everywhere around them.
Shri Swami Purohit: Saints who know their Selves, who control their minds, and feel neither desire nor anger, find Eternal Bliss everywhere.

Eknath Easwaran: Closing their eyes, steadying their breathing, and focusing their attention on the center of spiritual consciousness,
Mahatma Gandhi: That ascetic is ever free—who, having shut out the outward  sense-contacts, sits with his gaze fixed between the brows, outward and inward  breathing in the nostrils made equal; his senses, mind, and reason held in check;  rid of longing, fear and wrath; and intent on Freedom.
Shri Swami Purohit: Excluding external objects, his gaze fixed between the eyebrows, the inward and outward breathings passing equally through his nostrils;

Eknath Easwaran: the wise master their senses, mind, and intellect through meditation. Self-realization is their only goal. Freed from selfish desire, fear, and anger, they live in freedom always.
Mahatma Gandhi: That ascetic is ever free—who, having shut out the outward  sense-contacts, sits with his gaze fixed between the brows, outward and inward  breathing in the nostrils made equal; his senses, mind, and reason held in check;  rid of longing, fear and wrath; and intent on Freedom.
Shri Swami Purohit: Governing sense, mind and intellect, intent on liberation, free from desire, fear and anger, the sage is forever free.

Eknath Easwaran: Knowing me as the friend of all creatures, the Lord of the universe, the end of all offerings and all spiritual disciplines, they attain eternal peace.
Mahatma Gandhi: Knowing Me as the Acceptor of sacrifice and austerity, the great Lord of all  the worlds, the Friend of all creation, the yogi attains to peace.
Shri Swami Purohit: Knowing me as Him who gladly receives all offerings of austerity and sacrifice, as the Might Ruler of all the Worlds and the Friend of all beings, he passes to Eternal Peace.”

Eknath Easwaran: KRISHNA:  With your mind intent on me, Arjuna, discipline yourself with the practice of yoga. Depend on me completely. Listen, and I will dispel all your doubts; you will come to know me fully and be united with me.
Mahatma Gandhi: Hear, O Arjuna, how, with your mind rivetted on me, by practicing yoga and  making me the sole refuge, you shall, without doubt, know me fully.
Shri Swami Purohit: “Lord Shri Krishna said: Listen, O Arjuna! And I will tell you how you shall know Me in my Full perfection, practising meditation with your mind devoted to Me, and having Me for your refuge.

Eknath Easwaran: I will give you both jnana and vijnana. When both these are realized, there is nothing more you need to know.
Mahatma Gandhi: I will declare to you, in its entirety, this knowledge, combined with  discriminative knowledge, which when you have known there remains here  nothing more to be known.
Shri Swami Purohit: I will reveal to this knowledge unto you, and how it may be realised; which, once accomplished, there remains nothing else worth having in this life.

Eknath Easwaran: One person in many thousands may seek perfection, yet of these only a few reach the goal and come to realize me.
Mahatma Gandhi: Among thousands of men hardly one strives after perfection; among those  who strive hardly one knows Me in truth.
Shri Swami Purohit: Among thousands of men scarcely one strives for perfection, and even amongst those who gain occult powers, perhaps but one knows me in truth.

Eknath Easwaran: Earth, water, fire, air, akasha, mind, intellect, and ego  these are the eight divisions of my prakriti.
Mahatma Gandhi: Earth, Water, Fire, Air, Ether, Mind, Reason and Ego—thus eightfold is my  prakriti divided.
Shri Swami Purohit: Earth, water, fire, air, ether, mind, intellect and personality; this is the eightfold division of My Manifested Nature.

Eknath Easwaran: But beyond this I have another, higher nature, Arjuna; it supports the whole universe and is the source of life in all beings.
Mahatma Gandhi: This is My lower aspect; but know you My other aspect, the higher—which  is Jiva (the Vital Essence) by which, O Arjuna, this world is sustained.
Shri Swami Purohit: This is My inferior Nature; but distinct from this, O Valiant One, know you that my Superior Nature is the very Life which sustains the universe.

Eknath Easwaran: In these two aspects of my nature is the womb of all creation. The birth and dissolution of the cosmos itself take place in me.
Mahatma Gandhi: Know that these two compose the source from which all beings spring; I am  the origin and end of the entire universe.
Shri Swami Purohit: It is the womb of all being; for I am He by Whom the worlds were created and shall be dissolved.

Eknath Easwaran: There is nothing that exists separate from me, Arjuna. The entire universe is suspended from me as my necklace of jewels.
Mahatma Gandhi: There is nothing higher than I, O Arjuna; all this is strung on Me as a  row of gems upon a thread.
Shri Swami Purohit: O Arjuna! There is nothing higher than Me; all is strung upon Me as rows of pearls upon a thread.

Eknath Easwaran: Arjuna, I am the taste of pure water and the radiance of the sun and moon. I am the sacred word and the sound heard in air, and the courage of human beings.
Mahatma Gandhi: In water I am the savour, O Arjuna; in the sun and the moon I am the light;  the syllable AUM in all the Vedas; the sound in ether, and manliness in men.
Shri Swami Purohit: O Arjuna! I am the Fluidity in water, the Light in the sun and in the moon. I am the mystic syllable Om in the Vedic scriptures, the Sound in ether, the Virility in man.

Eknath Easwaran: I am the sweet fragrance in the earth and the radiance of fire; I am the life in every creature and the striving of the spiritual aspirant.
Mahatma Gandhi: I am the sweet fragrance in earth; the brilliance in fire; the life in all beings;  and the austerity in ascetics.
Shri Swami Purohit: I am the Fragrance of earth, the Brilliance of fire. I am the Life Force in all beings, and I am the Austerity of the ascetics.

Eknath Easwaran: My eternal seed, Arjuna, is to be found in every creature. I am the power of discrimination in those who are intelligent, and the glory   of the noble.
Mahatma Gandhi: Know Me, O Arjuna, to be the primeval seed of all beings; I am the reason of  rational beings and the splendour of the splendid.
Shri Swami Purohit: Know, O Arjuna, that I am the eternal Seed of being; I am the Intelligence of the intelligent, the Splendour of the resplendent.

Eknath Easwaran: In those who are strong, I am strength, free from passion and selfish attachment. I am desire itself, if that desire is in harmony with the purpose of life.
Mahatma Gandhi: Of the strong, I am the strength, divorced from lust and passion; in beings I  am desire undivorced from righteousness.
Shri Swami Purohit: I am the Strength of the strong, of them who are free from attachment and desire; and, O Arjuna, I am the Desire for righteousness.

Eknath Easwaran: . The states of sattva, rajas, and tamas come from me, but I am not in them.
Mahatma Gandhi: Know that all the manifestations of the three gunas, sattva, rajas, and tamas,  proceed from none but Me; yet I am not in them; they are in Me.
Shri Swami Purohit: Whatever be the nature of their life, whether it be pure or passionate or ignorant, they are all derived from Me. They are in Me, but I am not in them.

Eknath Easwaran: These three gunas deceive the world: people fail to look beyond them to me, supreme and imperishable.
Mahatma Gandhi: Befogged by these manifestations of the three gunas, the entire world fails to  recognize Me, the imperishable, as transcending them.
Shri Swami Purohit: The inhabitants of the world, misled by those natures which the Qualities have engendered, know not that I am higher than them all, and that I do not change.

Eknath Easwaran: The three gunas make up my divine maya, difficult to overcome. But they cross over this maya who take refuge in me.
Mahatma Gandhi: For this My divine delusive mystery made up of the three gunas is hard to  pierce; but those who make Me their sole refuge pierce the veil.
Shri Swami Purohit: Verily, this Divine Illusion of Phenomenon manifesting itself in the Qualities is difficult to surmount. Only they who devote themselves to Me and to Me alone can accomplish it.

Eknath Easwaran: Others are deluded by maya; performing evil deeds, they have no devotion to me. Having lost all discrimination, they follow the way of their lower nature.
Mahatma Gandhi: The deluded evil-doers, lowest of men, do not see refuge in Me; for, by  reason of this delusive mystery, they are bereft of knowledge and given to  devilish ways.
Shri Swami Purohit: The sinner, the ignorant, the vile, deprived of spiritual perception by the glamour of Illusion, and he who pursues a godless life – none of them shall find Me.

Eknath Easwaran: Good people come to worship me for different reasons. Some come to the spiritual life because of suffering, some in order to understand life; some come through a desire to achieve lifes purpose, and some come who are men and women of wisdom.
Mahatma Gandhi: Four types of well-doers are devoted to Me, O Arjuna; they are, O  Arjuna, the afflicted, the spiritual seeker, the material seeker, and the  enlightened.
Shri Swami Purohit: O Arjuna! The righteous who worship Me are grouped by stages: first, they who suffer, next they who desire knowledge, then they who thirst after truth, and lastly they who attain wisdom.

Eknath Easwaran: Unwavering in devotion, always united with me, the man or woman of wisdom surpasses all the others. To them I am the dearest beloved, and they are very dear to me.
Mahatma Gandhi: Of these the enlightened, ever attached to Me in single-minded devotion, is  the best; for to the enlightened I am exceedingly dear and he is dear to Me.
Shri Swami Purohit: Of all of these, he who has gained wisdom, who meditates on Me without ceasing, devoting himself only to Me, he is the best; for by the wise man I am exceedingly beloved and the wise man, too, is beloved by Me.

Eknath Easwaran: All those who follow the spiritual path are blessed. But the wise who are always established in union, for whom there is no higher goal than me, may be regarded as my very Self.
Mahatma Gandhi: All these are estimable indeed, but the enlightened I hold to be My very self;  for he, the true yogi, is stayed on Me alone, the supreme goal.
Shri Swami Purohit: Noble-minded are they all, but the wise man I hold as my own Self; for he, remaining always at peace with Me, makes me his final goal.

Eknath Easwaran: After many births the wise seek refuge in me, seeing me everywhere and in everything. Such great souls are very rare.
Mahatma Gandhi: At the end of many births the enlightened man finds refuge in Me; rare  indeed is this great soul to whom ‘Vasudeva is all'.
Shri Swami Purohit: After many lives, at last the wise man realises Me as I am. A man so enlightened that he sees God everywhere is very difficult to find.

Eknath Easwaran: There are others whose discrimination is misled by many desires. Following their own nature, they worship lower gods, practicing various rites.
Mahatma Gandhi: Men, bereft of knowledge by reason of various longings, seek refuge in  other gods, pinning their faith on diverse rites, guided by their own nature.
Shri Swami Purohit: They in whom wisdom is obscured by one desire or the other, worship the lesser Powers, practising many rites which vary according to their temperaments.

Eknath Easwaran: When a person is devoted to something with complete faith, I unify his faith in that.
Mahatma Gandhi: Whatever form one desires to worship in faith and devotion, in that very  form I make that faith of his secure.
Shri Swami Purohit: But whatever the form of worship, if the devotee have faith, then upon his faith in that worship do I set My own seal.

Eknath Easwaran: Then, when faith is completely unified, one gains the object of devotion. In this way, every desire is fulfilled by me.
Mahatma Gandhi: Possessed of that faith he seeks a propitiate that one, and obtains  there through his longings, dispensed in truth by none but Me.
Shri Swami Purohit: If he worships one form alone with real faith, then shall his desires be fulfilled through that only; for thus have I ordained.

Eknath Easwaran: Those whose understanding is small attain only transient satisfaction: those who worship the gods go to the gods. But my devotees come to me.
Mahatma Gandhi: But limited is the fruit that falls to those shortsighted ones; those who  worship the gods go to the gods, those who worship Me come unto Me.
Shri Swami Purohit: The fruit that comes to men of limited insight is, after all, finite. They who worship the Lower Powers attain them; but those who worship Me come unto Me alone.

Eknath Easwaran: Through lack of understanding, people believe that I, the Unmanifest, have entered into some form. They fail to realize my true nature, which transcends birth and death.
Mahatma Gandhi: Not knowing My transcendent, imperishable, supreme character, the  undiscerning think Me who am unmanifest to have become manifest.
Shri Swami Purohit: The ignorant think of Me, who am the Unmanifested Spirit, as if I were really in human form. They do not understand that My Superior Nature is changeless and most excellent.

Eknath Easwaran: Few see through the veil of maya. The world, deluded, does not know that I am without birth and changeless.
Mahatma Gandhi: Veiled by the delusive mystery created by My unique power, I am not  manifest to all; this bewildered world does not recognize Me, birthless and  changeless.
Shri Swami Purohit: I am not visible to all, for I am enveloped by the illusion of Phenomenon. This deluded world does not know Me as the Unborn and the Imperishable.

Eknath Easwaran: I know everything about the past, the present, and the future, Arjuna; but there is no one who knows me completely.
Mahatma Gandhi: I know, O Arjuna, all creatures past, present and to be; but no one knows  Me.
Shri Swami Purohit: I know, O Arjuna, all beings in the past, the present and the future; but they do not know Me.

Eknath Easwaran: Delusion arises from the duality of attraction and aversion, Arjuna; every creature is deluded by these from birth.
Mahatma Gandhi: All creatures in this universe are bewildered, O Arjuna, by virtue of the  delusion of the pairs of opposite sprung from likes and dislikes, O Arjuna.
Shri Swami Purohit: O brave Arjuna! Man lives in a fairy world, deceived by the glamour of opposite sensations, infatuated by desire and aversion.

Eknath Easwaran: But those who have freed themselves from all wrongdoing are firmly established in worship of me. Their actions are pure, and they are free from the delusion caused by the pairs of opposites.
Mahatma Gandhi: But those virtuous men whose sin has come to an end, freed from delusion  and of the pairs of opposites, worship Me in steadfast faith.
Shri Swami Purohit: But those who act righteously, in whom sin has been destroyed, who are free from the infatuation of the conflicting emotions, they worship Me with firm resolution.

Eknath Easwaran: Those who take refuge in me, striving for liberation from old age and death, come to know Brahman, the Self, and the nature of all action.
Mahatma Gandhi: Those who endeavour for freedom from age and death by taking refuge in  Me, know in full that Brahman, Adhyatma and all Karma.
Shri Swami Purohit: Those who make Me their refuge, who strive for liberation from decay and Death, they realise the Supreme Spirit, which is their own real Self, and in which all action finds its consummation.

Eknath Easwaran: Those who see me ruling the cosmos, who see me in the adhibhuta, the adhidaiva, and the adhiyajna, are conscious of me even at the time of death.
Mahatma Gandhi: Those who know Me, including Adhibhuta, Adhidaiva, Adhiyajna,  possessed of even-mindedness, they know Me even at the time of passing away.
Shri Swami Purohit: Those who see Me in the life of the world, in the universal sacrifice, and as pure Divinity, keeping their minds steady, they live in Me, even in the crucial hour of death.”

Eknath Easwaran: ARJUNA:  O Krishna, what is Brahman, and what is the nature of action? What is the adhyatma, the adhibhuta, the adhidaiva?
Mahatma Gandhi: What is that Brahman? What is Adhyatma? What Karma, O Krishna?  What is called Adhibhuta? And what Adhidaiva?
Shri Swami Purohit: “Arjuna asked: O Lord of Lords! What is that which men call the Supreme Spirit, what is man’s Spiritual Nature, and what is the Law? What is Matter and what is Divinity?

Eknath Easwaran: What is the adhiyajna, the supreme sacrifice, and how is it to be offered? How are the self-controlled united with you at the time of death?
Mahatma Gandhi: And who here in this body is Adhiyajna and how? And how at the time of  death are You to be known by the self-controlled?  The Lord Said:
Shri Swami Purohit: Who is it who rules the spirit sacrifice in many; and at the time of death how may those who have learned self-control come to the knowledge of You?

Eknath Easwaran: KRISHNA:  My highest nature, the imperishable Brahman, gives every creature its existence and lives in every creature as the adhyatma. My action is creation and the bringing forth of creatures.
Mahatma Gandhi: The Supreme, the Imperishable is Brahman; its manifestation is Adhyatma;  the creative process whereby all beings are created is called Karma.
Shri Swami Purohit: The Lord Shri Krishna replied: The Supreme Spirit is the Highest Imperishable Self, and Its Nature is spiritual consciousness. The worlds have been created and are supported by an emanation from the Spirit which is called the Law.

Eknath Easwaran: The adhibhuta is the perishable body; the adhidaiva is Purusha, eternal spirit. The adhiyajna, the supreme sacrifice, is made to me as the Lord within you.
Mahatma Gandhi: Adhibhuta is My perishable form; Adhidaivata is the individual self in that  form; and O best among the embodied, Adhiyajna am I in this body, purified by  sacrifice.
Shri Swami Purohit: Matter consists of the forms that perish; Divinity is the Supreme Self; and He who inspires the spirit of sacrifice in man, O noblest of your race, is I Myself, Who now stand in human form before you.

Eknath Easwaran: Those who remember me at the time of death will come to me. Do not doubt this.
Mahatma Gandhi: And he who, at the last hour remembering Me only, departs leaving the  body, enters into Me; of that there is no doubt.
Shri Swami Purohit: Whosoever at the time of death thinks only of Me, and thinking thus leaves the body and goes forth, assuredly he will know Me.

Eknath Easwaran: Whatever occupies the mind at the time of death determines the destination of the dying; always they will tend toward that state of being.
Mahatma Gandhi: Or whatever form a man continually contemplates, that same he remembers  in the hour of death, and to that very form he goes, O Arjuna.
Shri Swami Purohit: On whatever sphere of being the mind of a man may be intent at the time of death, towards that place he will go.

Eknath Easwaran: Therefore, remember me at all times and fight on. With your heart and mind intent on me, you will surely come to me.
Mahatma Gandhi: Therefore at all times remember Me and fight on; your mind and reason thus  on Me fixed you shall surely come to Me.
Shri Swami Purohit: Therefore meditate always on Me, and fight; if your mind and your reason be fixed on Me, to Me shall you surely come.

Eknath Easwaran: When you make your mind one-pointed through regular practice of meditation, you will find the supreme glory of the Lord.
Mahatma Gandhi: With thought steadied by constant practice, and wandering nowhere, he who  meditates on the Supreme Celestial Being, O Arjuna, goes to Him.
Shri Swami Purohit: He whose mind does not wander, and who is engaged in constant meditation, attains the Supreme Spirit.

Eknath Easwaran: The Lord is the supreme poet, the first cause, the sovereign ruler, subtler than the tiniest particle, the support of all, inconceivable, bright as the sun, beyond darkness.
Mahatma Gandhi: Whoso, at the time of death, with unwavering mind, with devotion, and  fixing the breath rightly between the brows by the power of yoga, meditates on  the Sage, the Ancient, the Ruler, subtler than the subtlest, the Supporter of all,  the Inconceivable, glorious as the sun beyond the darkness,—he goes to that  Supreme Celestial Being.
Shri Swami Purohit: Whoso meditates on the Omniscient, the Ancient, more minute than the atom, yet the Ruler and Upholder of all, Unimaginable, Brilliant like the Sun, Beyond the reach of darkness;

Eknath Easwaran: Remembering him in this way at the time of death, through devotion and the power of meditation, with your mind completely stilled and your concentration fixed in the center of spiritual awareness between the eyebrows, you will realize the supreme Lord.
Mahatma Gandhi: Whoso, at the time of death, with unwavering mind, with devotion, and  fixing the breath rightly between the brows by the power of yoga, meditates on  the Sage, the Ancient, the Ruler, subtler than the subtlest, the Supporter of all,  the Inconceivable, glorious as the sun beyond the darkness,—he goes to that  Supreme Celestial Being.
Shri Swami Purohit: He who leaves the body with mind unmoved and filled with devotion, by the power of his meditation gathering between his eyebrows his whole vital energy, attains the Supreme.

Eknath Easwaran: I will tell you briefly of the eternal state all scriptures affirm, which can be entered only by those who are self-controlled and free from selfish passions. Those whose lives are dedicated to Brahman attain this supreme goal.
Mahatma Gandhi: That which the knowers of the Vedas call the Imperishable (or that word  which the knowers of the Vedas repeat), wherein the ascetics freed from  passion enter and desiring which they practice brahmacharya, that Goal (or  Word) I will declare to you in brief.
Shri Swami Purohit: Now I will speak briefly of the imperishable goal, proclaimed by those versed in the scriptures, which the mystic attains when free from passion, and for which he is content to undergo the vow of continence.

Eknath Easwaran: Remembering me at the time of death, close down the doors of the senses and place the mind in the heart. Then, while absorbed in meditation, focus all energy upwards to the head.
Mahatma Gandhi: Closing all the gates, locking up the mind in the hridaya, fixing his breath  within the head, carried in yogic meditation;
Shri Swami Purohit: Closing the gates of the body, drawing the forces of his mind into the heart and by the power of meditation concentrating his vital energy in the brain;

Eknath Easwaran: Repeating in this state the divine name, the syllable Om that represents the changeless Brahman, you will go forth from the body and attain the supreme goal.
Mahatma Gandhi: Whoso departs leaving the body uttering AUM—Brahman in one  syllable—repeatedly thinking on Me, he reaches the highest state.
Shri Swami Purohit: Repeating Om, the Symbol of Eternity, holding Me always in remembrance, he who thus leaves his body and goes forth reaches the Spirit Supreme.

Eknath Easwaran: I am easily attained by the person who always remembers me and is attached to nothing else. Such a person is a true yogi, Arjuna.
Mahatma Gandhi: That yogi easily wins to Me, O Arjuna, who, ever attached to Me, constantly  remembers Me with undivided mind.
Shri Swami Purohit: To him who thinks constantly of Me, and of nothing else, to such an ever-faithful devotee, O Arjuna, am I ever accessible.

Eknath Easwaran: Great souls make their lives perfect and discover me; they are freed from mortality and the suffering of this separate existence.
Mahatma Gandhi: Great souls, having come to Me, reach the highest perfection; they come not  again to birth, unlasting and (withal) an abode of misery.
Shri Swami Purohit: Coming thus unto Me, these great souls go no more to the misery and death of earthly life, for they have gained perfection.

Eknath Easwaran: Every creature in the universe is subject to rebirth, Arjuna, except the one who is united with me.
Mahatma Gandhi: From the world of Brahma down, all the worlds are subject to return, O  Arjuna; but on coming to Me there is no rebirth.
Shri Swami Purohit: The worlds, with the whole realm of creation, come and go; but, O Arjuna, whoso comes to Me, for him there is nor rebirth.

Eknath Easwaran: Those who understand the cosmic laws know that the Day of Brahma ends after a thousand yugas and the Night of Brahma ends after a thousand yugas.
Mahatma Gandhi: Those men indeed know what is Day and what is Night, who know that  Brahma's day lasts a thousand yugas and that his night too is a thousand yugas  long.
Shri Swami Purohit: Those who understand the cosmic day and cosmic night know that one day of creation is a thousand cycles, and that the night is of equal length.

Eknath Easwaran: When the day of Brahma dawns, forms are brought forth from the Unmanifest; when the night of Brahma comes, these forms merge in the Formless again.
Mahatma Gandhi: At the coming of Day all the manifest spring forth from the Unmanifest, and  at the coming of Night they are dissolved into that same Unmanifest.
Shri Swami Purohit: At the dawning of that day all objects in manifestation stream forth from the Unmanifest, and when evening falls they are dissolved into It again.

Eknath Easwaran: This multitude of beings is created and destroyed again and again in the succeeding days and nights of Brahma.
Mahatma Gandhi: This same multitude of creatures come to birth, O Arjuna, again and again;  they are dissolved at the coming of Night, whether they will or not; and at the  break of Day they are re-born.
Shri Swami Purohit: The same multitude of beings, which have lived on earth so often, all are dissolved as the night of the universe approaches, to issue forth anew when morning breaks. Thus is it ordained.

Eknath Easwaran: But beyond this formless state there is another, unmanifested reality, which is eternal and is not dissolved when the cosmos is destroyed.
Mahatma Gandhi: But higher than the Unmanifest is another Unmanifest Being, everlasting,  which perishes not when all creatures perish.
Shri Swami Purohit: In truth, therefore, there is the Eternal Unmanifest, which is beyond and above the Unmanifest Spirit of Creation, which is never destroyed when all these being perish.

Eknath Easwaran: Those who realize lifes supreme goal know that I am unmanifested and unchanging. Having come home to me, they never return to separate existence.
Mahatma Gandhi: This Unmanifest, named the Imperishable, is declared to be the highest goal.  For those who reach it there is no return. That is my highest abode.
Shri Swami Purohit: The wise say that the Unmanifest and Indestructible is the highest goal of all; when once That is reached, there is no return. That is My Blessed Home.

Eknath Easwaran: This supreme Lord who pervades all existence, the true Self of all creatures, may be realized through undivided love.
Mahatma Gandhi: This Supreme Being, O Arjuna, may be won by undivided devotion; in It all  beings dwell, by It all is pervaded.
Shri Swami Purohit: O Arjuna! That Highest God, in Whom all beings abide, and Who pervades the entire universe, is reached only by wholehearted devotion.

Eknath Easwaran: There are two paths, Arjuna, which the soul may follow at the time of death. One leads to rebirth and the other to liberation.
Mahatma Gandhi: Now I will tell you, Arjuna, the conditions which determine the  exemption from return, as also the return, of yogins after they pass away hence.
Shri Swami Purohit: Now I will tell you, O Arjuna, of the times at which, if the mystics go forth, they do not return, and at which they go forth only to return.

Eknath Easwaran: The six months of the northern path of the sun, the path of light, of fire, of day, of the bright fortnight, leads knowers of Brahman to the supreme goal.
Mahatma Gandhi: Fire, Light, Day, the Bright Fortnight, the six months of the Northern  Solstice—through these departing men knowing Brahman go to Brahman.
Shri Swami Purohit: If knowing the Supreme Spirit the sage goes forth with fire and light, in the daytime, in the fortnight of the waxing moon and in the six months before the Northern summer solstice, he will attain the Supreme.

Eknath Easwaran: The six months of the southern path of the sun, the path of smoke, of night, of the dark fortnight, leads other souls to the light of the moon and to rebirth.
Mahatma Gandhi: Smoke, Night, the Dark Fortnight, the six months of the Southern  Solstice—There through the yogin attains to the lunar light and from there returns.
Shri Swami Purohit: But if he departs in gloom, at night, during the fortnight of the waning moon and in the six months before the Southern solstice, then he reaches but lunar light and he will be born again.

Eknath Easwaran: These two paths, the light and the dark, are said to be eternal, leading some to liberation and others to rebirth.
Mahatma Gandhi: These two paths—bright and dark—are deemed to be the eternal paths of  the world; by the one a man goes to return not, by the other he returns again.
Shri Swami Purohit: These bright and dark paths out of the world have always existed. Whoso takes the former, returns not; he who chooses the latter, returns.

Eknath Easwaran: Once you have known these two paths, Arjuna, you can never be deluded again. Attain this knowledge through perseverance in yoga.
Mahatma Gandhi: The Yogin knowing these two paths falls not into delusion, O Arjuna;  therefore, at all times, O Arjuna, remain steadfast in yoga.
Shri Swami Purohit: O Arjuna! The saint knowing these paths is not confused. Therefore meditate perpetually.

Eknath Easwaran: There is merit in studying the scriptures, in selfless service, austerity, and giving, but the practice of meditation carries you beyond all these to the supreme abode of the highest Lord.
Mahatma Gandhi: Whatever fruit of good deeds is laid down as accruing from (a study of) the  Vedas, from sacrifices, austerities, and acts of charity—all that the yogin  transcends, on knowing this, and reaches the Supreme and Primal Abode.
Shri Swami Purohit: The sage who knows this passes beyond all merit that comes from the study of the scriptures, from sacrifice, from austerities and charity, and reaches the Supreme Primeval Abode.”

Eknath Easwaran: KRISHNA:  Because of your faith, I shall tell you the most profound of secrets: obtaining both jnana and vijnana, you will be free from all evil.
Mahatma Gandhi: I will now declare to you, who are uncensorious, this mysterious knowledge,  together with discriminative knowledge, knowing which you shall be released  from ill.
Shri Swami Purohit: “Lord Shri Krishna said: I will now reveal to you, since you doubt not, that profound mysticism, which when followed by experience, shall liberate you from sin.

Eknath Easwaran: This royal knowledge, this royal secret, is the greatest purifier. Righteous and imperishable, it is a joy to practice and can be directly experienced.
Mahatma Gandhi: This is the king of sciences, the king of mysteries, pure and sovereign, capable  of direct comprehension, the essence of dharma, easy to practice, changeless.
Shri Swami Purohit: This is the Premier Science, the Sovereign Secret, the Purest and Best; intuitional, righteous; and to him who practises it pleasant beyond measure.

Eknath Easwaran: But those who have no faith in the supreme law of life do not find me, Arjuna. They return to the world, passing from death to death.
Mahatma Gandhi: Men who have no faith in this doctrine, O Arjuna, far from coming to Me,  return repeatedly to the path of this world of death.
Shri Swami Purohit: They who have no faith in this teaching cannot find Me, but remain lost in the purlieus of this perishable world.

Eknath Easwaran: I pervade the entire universe in my unmanifested form. All creatures find their existence in me, but I am not limited by them.
Mahatma Gandhi: By Me, unmanifest in form, this whole world is pervaded; all beings are in  Me, I am not in them.
Shri Swami Purohit: The whole world is pervaded by Me, yet My form is not seen. All living things have their being in Me, yet I am not limited by them.

Eknath Easwaran: Behold my divine mystery! These creatures do not really dwell in me, and though I bring them forth and support them, I am not confined within them.
Mahatma Gandhi: And yet those beings are not in Me. That indeed is My unique power as Lord!  Sustainer of all beings, I am not in them; My Self brings them into existence.
Shri Swami Purohit: Nevertheless, they do not consciously abide in Me. Such is My Divine Sovereignty that though I, the Supreme Self, am the cause and upholder of all, yet I remain outside.

Eknath Easwaran: They move in me as the winds move in every direction in space.
Mahatma Gandhi: As the mighty wind, moving everywhere, is ever contained in ether, even so  know that all beings are contained in Me.
Shri Swami Purohit: As the mighty wind, though moving everywhere, has no resting place but space, so have all these beings no home but Me.

Eknath Easwaran: At the end of the eon these creatures return to unmanifested matter; at the beginning of the next cycle I send them forth again.
Mahatma Gandhi: All beings, O Arjuna, merge into my prakriti, at the end of a kalpa, and I  send them forth again when a kalpa begins.
Shri Swami Purohit: All beings, O Arjuna, return at the close of every cosmic cycle into the realm of Nature, which is a part of Me, and at the beginning of the next I send them forth again.

Eknath Easwaran: Controlling my prakriti, again and again I bring forth these myriad forms and subject them to the laws of prakriti.
Mahatma Gandhi: Resorting to my prakriti, I send forth again and again this multitude of  beings, powerless under the sway of prakriti.
Shri Swami Purohit: With the help of Nature, again and again I pour forth the whole multitude of beings, whether they will or no, for they are ruled by My Will.

Eknath Easwaran: None of these actions binds me, Arjuna. I am unattached to them, so they do not disturb my nature.
Mahatma Gandhi: But all this activity, O Arjuna, does not bind Me, seated as one  indifferent, unattached to it.
Shri Swami Purohit: But these acts of mine do not bind Me. I remain outside and unattached.

Eknath Easwaran: Under my watchful eye the laws of nature take their course. Thus is the world set in motion; thus the animate and the inanimate are created.
Mahatma Gandhi: With me as Presiding Witness, prakriti gives birth to all that moves and does  not move; and because of this, O Arjuna, the wheel of the world keeps going.
Shri Swami Purohit: Under my guidance, Nature produces all things movable and immovable. Thus it is, O Arjuna, that this universe revolves.

Eknath Easwaran: The immature do not look beyond physical appearances to see my true nature as the Lord of all creation.
Mahatma Gandhi: Not knowing My transcendent nature as the sovereign Lord of all beings,  fools condemn Me incarnated as man.
Shri Swami Purohit: Fools disregard Me, seeing Me clad in human form. They know not that in My higher nature I am the Lord-God of all.

Eknath Easwaran: The knowledge of such deluded people is empty; their lives are fraught with disaster and evil, and their work and hopes are all in vain.
Mahatma Gandhi: Vain are the hopes, actions and knowledge of those witless ones who have  resorted to the delusive nature of monsters and devils.
Shri Swami Purohit: Their hopes are vain, their actions worthless, their knowledge futile; they are without sense, deceitful, barbarous and godless.

Eknath Easwaran: But truly great souls seek my divine nature. They worship me with a one-pointed mind, having realized that I am the eternal source of all.
Mahatma Gandhi: But those great souls who resort to the divine nature, O Arjuna, know Me as  the Imperishable Source of all beings and worship Me with an undivided mind.
Shri Swami Purohit: But the Great Souls, O Arjuna! Filled with My Divine Spirit, they worship Me, they fix their minds on Me and on Me alone, for they know that I am the imperishable Source of being.

Eknath Easwaran: Constantly striving, they make firm their resolve and worship me without wavering. Full of devotion, they sing of my divine glory.
Mahatma Gandhi: Always declaring My glory, striving in steadfast faith, they do Me devout  homage; ever attached to Me, they worship Me.
Shri Swami Purohit: Always extolling Me, strenuous, firm in their vows, prostrating themselves before Me, they worship Me continually with concentrated devotion.

Eknath Easwaran: Others follow the path of jnana, spiritual wisdom. They see that where there is One, that One is me; where there are many, all are me; they see my face everywhere.
Mahatma Gandhi: Yet others, with knowledge-sacrifice, worship Me, who am to be seen  everywhere, as one, as different or as many.
Shri Swami Purohit: Others worship Me with full consciousness as the One, the Manifold, the Omnipresent, the Universal.

Eknath Easwaran: I am the ritual and the sacrifice; I am true medicine and the mantram. I am the offering and the fire which consumes it, and the one to whom it is offered.
Mahatma Gandhi: I am the sacrificial vow; I am the sacrifice; I the ancestral oblation; I the herb;  I the sacred text; I the clarified butter; I the fire; I the burnt offering.
Shri Swami Purohit: I am the Oblation, the Sacrifice and the Worship; I am the Fuel and the Chant, I am the Butter offered to the fire, I am the Fire itself, and I am the Act of offering.

Eknath Easwaran: I am the father and mother of this universe, and its grandfather too; I am its entire support. I am the sum of all knowledge, the purifier, the syllable Om; I am the sacred scriptures, the Rig, Yajur, and Sama Vedas.
Mahatma Gandhi: Of this universe I am the Father, Mother, Creator, Grandsire: I am what is to  be known, the sacred syllable AUM; the Rig, the Saman and the Yajus;
Shri Swami Purohit: I am the Father of the universe and its Mother; I am its Nourisher and its Grandfather; I am the Knowable and the Pure; I am Om; and I am the Sacred Scriptures.

Eknath Easwaran: I am the goal of life, the Lord and support of all, the inner witness, the abode of all. I am the only refuge, the one true friend; I am the beginning, the staying, and the end of creation; I am the womb and the eternal seed.
Mahatma Gandhi: I am the Goal, the Sustainer, the Lord, the Witness, the Abode, the Refuge,  the Friend; the Origin, the End the Preservation, the Treasure house, the  Imperishable Seed.
Shri Swami Purohit: I am the Goal, the Sustainer, the Lord, the Witness, the Home, the Shelter, the Lover and the Origin; I am Life and Death; I am the Fountain and the Seed Imperishable.

Eknath Easwaran: I am heat; I give and withhold the rain. I am immortality and I am death; I am what is and what is not.
Mahatma Gandhi: I give heat; I hold back and pour forth rain; I am deathlessness and also  death. O Arjuna, Being and not-Being as well.
Shri Swami Purohit: I am the Heat of the Sun, I release and hold back the Rains. I am Death and Immortality; I am Being and Not-Being.

Eknath Easwaran: Those who follow the rituals given in the Vedas, who offer sacrifices and take soma, free themselves from evil and attain the vast heaven of the gods, where they enjoy celestial pleasures.
Mahatma Gandhi: Followers of the three Vedas, who drink the soma juice and are purged of  sin, worship Me with sacrifice and pray for going to heaven; they reach the holy  world of the gods and enjoy in heaven the divine joys of the gods.
Shri Swami Purohit: Those who are versed in the scriptures, who drink the mystic Soma-juice and are purified from sin, but who while worshipping Me with sacrifices pray that I will lead them to heaven; they reach the holy world where lives the Controller of the Powers of Nature, and they enjoy the feasts of Paradise.

Eknath Easwaran: When they have enjoyed these fully, their merit is exhausted and they return to this land of death. Thus observing Vedic rituals but caught in an endless chain of desires, they come and go.
Mahatma Gandhi: They enjoy the vast world of heaven, and their merit spent, they enter the  world of the mortals; thus those who, following the Vedic law, long for the fruit  of their action earn but the round of birth and death.
Shri Swami Purohit: Yet although they enjoy the spacious glories of Paradise, nevertheless, when their merit is exhausted, they are born again into this world of mortals. They have followed the letter of the scriptures, yet because they have sought but to fulfill their own desires, they must depart and return again and again.

Eknath Easwaran: Those who worship me and meditate on me constantly, without any other thought  I will provide for all their needs.
Mahatma Gandhi: As for those who worship Me, thinking on Me alone and nothing else, ever  attached to Me, I bear the burden of getting them what they need.
Shri Swami Purohit: But if a man will meditate on Me and Me alone, and will worship Me always and everywhere, I will take upon Myself the fulfillment of his aspiration, and I will safeguard whatsoever he shall attain.

Eknath Easwaran: Those who worship other gods with faith and devotion also worship me, Arjuna, even if they do not observe the usual forms.
Mahatma Gandhi: Even those who, devoted to other gods, worship them in full faith, even  they, O Arjuna, worship none but Me, though not according to the rule.
Shri Swami Purohit: Even those who worship the lesser Powers, if they do so with faith, they thereby worship Me, though not in the right way.

Eknath Easwaran: I am the object of all worship, its enjoyer and Lord. But those who fail to realize my true nature must be reborn.
Mahatma Gandhi: For I am the Acceptor and the Director of all sacrifices; but not recognizing  Me as I am, they go astray.
Shri Swami Purohit: I am the willing recipient of sacrifice, and I am its true Lord. But these do not know me in truth, and so they sink back.

Eknath Easwaran: Those who worship the devas will go to the realm of the devas; those who worship their ancestors will be united with them after death. Those who worship phantoms will become phantoms; but my devotees will come to me.
Mahatma Gandhi: Those who worship the gods go to the gods; those who worship the manes  go to the manes; those who worship the spirits go to the spirits; but those who  worship Me come to Me.
Shri Swami Purohit: The votaries of the lesser Powers go to them; the devotees of spirits go to them; they who worship the Powers of Darkness, to such Powers shall they go; and so, too, those who worship Me shall come to Me.

Eknath Easwaran: Whatever I am offered in devotion with a pure heart  a leaf, a flower, fruit, or water  I accept with joy.
Mahatma Gandhi: Any offering of leaf, flower, fruit or water, made to Me in devotion, by an  earnest soul, I lovingly accept.
Shri Swami Purohit: Whatever a man offers to Me, whether it be a leaf, or a flower, of fruit, or water, I accept it, for it is offered with devotion and purity of mind.

Eknath Easwaran: Whatever you do, make it an offering to me  the food you eat, the sacrifices you make, the help you give, even your suffering.
Mahatma Gandhi: Whatever you do, whatever you eat, whatever you offer as  sacrifice or gift, whatever austerity you do perform, O Arjuna, dedicate all  to Me.
Shri Swami Purohit: Whatever you do, whatever you do eat, whatever you do sacrifice and give, whatever austerities you practisest, do all as an offering to Me.

Eknath Easwaran: In this way you will be freed from the bondage of karma, and from its results both pleasant and painful. Then, firm in renunciation and yoga, with your heart free, you will come to me.
Mahatma Gandhi: So doing you shall be released from the bondage of action, yielding good  and evil fruit; having accomplished both renunciation and performance, you  shall be released (from birth and death) and come unto Me.
Shri Swami Purohit: So shall your action be attended by no result, either good or bad; but through the spirit of renunciation you shall come to Me and be free.

Eknath Easwaran: I look upon all creatures equally; none are less dear to me and none more dear. But those who worship me with love live in me, and I come to life in them.
Mahatma Gandhi: I am the same to all beings; with Me there is non disfavoured, none  favoured; but those who worship Me with devotion are in Me and I in them.
Shri Swami Purohit: I am the same to all beings. I favour none, and I hate none. But those who worship Me devotedly, they live in Me, and I in them.

Eknath Easwaran: Even sinners become holy when they take refuge in me alone.
Mahatma Gandhi: A sinner, howsoever great, if he turns to Me with undivided devotion, must  indeed be counted a saint; for he has a settled resolve.
Shri Swami Purohit: Even the most sinful, if he worship Me with his whole heart, shall be considered righteous, for he is treading the right path.

Eknath Easwaran: Quickly their souls conform to dharma and they attain to boundless peace. Never forget this, Arjuna: no one who is devoted to me will ever come to harm.
Mahatma Gandhi: For soon he becomes righteous and wins everlasting peace; know for a  certainty, O Arjuna, that my bhakta never perishes.
Shri Swami Purohit: He shall attain spirituality before long, and Eternal Peace shall be his. O Arjuna! Believe me, My devotee is never lost.

Eknath Easwaran: All those who take refuge in me, whatever their birth, race, sex, or caste, will attain the supreme goal; this realization can be attained even by those whom society scorns.
Mahatma Gandhi: For finding refuge in Me, even those who though are born of the womb of  sin, women, vaishyas, and shudras too, reach the supreme goal.
Shri Swami Purohit: For even the children of sinful parents, and those miscalled the weaker sex, and merchants, and labourers, if only they will make Me their refuge, they shall attain the Highest.

Eknath Easwaran: Kings and sages too seek this goal with devotion. Therefore, having been born in this transient and forlorn world, give all your love to me.
