Shastra does not mean the rites and formulae laid down in the so-called  dharmashastra, but the path of self-restraint laid down by the seers and the  saints.
Shri Swami Purohit: But he who neglects the commands of the scriptures, and follows the promptings of passion, he does not attain perfection, happiness or the final goal.

Eknath Easwaran: Therefore let the scriptures be your guide in what to do and what not to do. Understand their teachings; then act in accordance with them.
Mahatma Gandhi: Therefore let shastra be your authority for determining what ought to be  done and what ought not to be done; ascertain you the rule of the shastra and  do your task here (accordingly).
Shri Swami Purohit: Therefore whenever there is doubt whether you should do a thing or not, let the scriptures guide your conduct. In the light of the scriptures should you labour the whole of your life.”

Eknath Easwaran: ARJUNA  O Krishna, what is the state of those who disregard the scriptures but still worship with faith? Do they act from sattva, rajas, or tamas?
Mahatma Gandhi: What, then, O Krishna, is the position of those who forsake the rule of Shastra  and yet worship with faith? Do they act from sattva or rajas or tamas?  The Lord Said:
Shri Swami Purohit: “Arjuna asked: My Lord! Those who do acts of sacrifice, not according to the scriptures but nevertheless with implicit faith, what is their condition? Is it one of Purity, of Passion or of Ignorance?

Eknath Easwaran: KRISHNA  Every creature is born with faith of some kind, either sattvic, rajasic, or tamasic. Listen, and I will describe each to you.
Mahatma Gandhi: Threefold is the faith of men, an expression of their nature in each case; it is  sattvika, rajas or tamasa. Hear you of it.
Shri Swami Purohit: Lord Shri Krishna replied: Man has an inherent faith in one or another of the Qualities – Purity, Passion and Ignorance. Now listen.

Eknath Easwaran: Our faith conforms to our nature, Arjuna. Human nature is made of faith. A person is what his shraddha is.
Mahatma Gandhi: The faith of every man is in accord with his innate character; man is made up  of faith; whatever his object of faith, even so is he.
Shri Swami Purohit: The faith of every man conforms to his nature. By nature he is full of faith. He is in fact what his faith makes him.

Eknath Easwaran: Those who are sattvic worship the forms of God; those who are rajasic worship power and wealth. Those who are tamasic worship spirits and ghosts.
Mahatma Gandhi: Sattvika persons worship the gods; rajas ones, the Yakshas and Rakshasas;  and others—men of tamas—worship manes and spirits.
Shri Swami Purohit: The Pure worship the true God; the Passionate, the powers of wealth and magic; the Ignorant, the spirits of the dead and of the lower orders of nature.

Eknath Easwaran: Some invent harsh penances. Motivated by hypocrisy and egotism,
Mahatma Gandhi: Those men who, wedded to pretentiousness and arrogance, possessed by the  violence of lust and passion, practice fierce austerity not ordained by shastra;
Shri Swami Purohit: Those who practise austerities not commanded by scripture, who are slaves to hypocrisy and egotism, who are carried away by the fury of desire and passion,

Eknath Easwaran: they torture their innocent bodies and me who dwells within. Blinded by their strength and passion, they act and think like demons.
Mahatma Gandhi: They, whilst they torture the several elements that make up their bodies,  torture Me too dwelling in them; know them to be of unholy resolves.
Shri Swami Purohit: They are ignorant. They torment the organs of the body; and they harass Me also, Who lives within. Know that they are devoted to evil.

Eknath Easwaran: The three kinds of faith express themselves in the habits of those who hold them: in the food they like, the work they do, the disciplines they practice, the gifts they give. Listen, and I will describe their different ways.
Mahatma Gandhi: Of three kinds again is the food that is dear to each; so also are sacrifice,  austerity, and charity. Hear how they differ.
Shri Swami Purohit: The food which men enjoy is also threefold, like the ways of sacrifice, austerity and almsgiving. Listen to the distinction.

Eknath Easwaran: Sattvic people enjoy food that is mild, tasty, substantial, agreeable, and nourishing, food that promotes health, strength, cheerfulness, and longevity.
Mahatma Gandhi: Victuals that add to one's years, vitality, strength, health, happiness and  appetite; are savoury, rich, substantial and inviting, are dear to the sattvika.
Shri Swami Purohit: The foods that prolong life and increase purity, vigour, health, cheerfulness and happiness are those that are delicious, soothing, substantial and agreeable. These are loved by the Pure.

Eknath Easwaran: Rajasic people like food that is salty or bitter, hot, sour, or spicy  food that promotes pain, discomfort, and disease.
Mahatma Gandhi: Victuals that are bitter, sour, salty, over-hot, spicy, dry, burning, and causing  pain, bitterness and disease, are dear to rajasa.
Shri Swami Purohit: Those in whom Passion is dominant like foods that are bitter, sour, salty, over-hot, pungent, dry and burning. These produce unhappiness, repentance and disease.

Eknath Easwaran: Tamasic people like overcooked, stale, leftover, and impure food, food that has lost its taste and nutritional value.
Mahatma Gandhi: Food which has become cold, insipid, putrid, stale, discarded and unfit for  sacrifice, is dear to the tamasa.
Shri Swami Purohit: The Ignorant love food which is stale, not nourishing, putrid and corrupt, the leavings of others and unclean.

Eknath Easwaran: The sattvic perform sacrifices with their entire mind fixed on the purpose of the sacrifice. Without thought of reward, they follow the teachings of the scriptures.
Mahatma Gandhi: That sacrifice is sattvika which is willingly offered as a duty without desire  for fruit and according to the rule.
Shri Swami Purohit: Sacrifice is Pure when it is offered by one who does not covet the fruit thereof, when it is done according to the commands of scripture, and with implicit faith that the sacrifice is a duty.

Eknath Easwaran: The rajasic perform sacrifices for the sake of show and the good it will bring them.
Mahatma Gandhi: But when sacrifice is offered with an eye to fruit and for vain glory, know, O  Arjuna, that it is rajasa.
Shri Swami Purohit: Sacrifice which is performed for the sake of its results, or for self-glorification – that, O best of Aryans, is the product of Passion.

Eknath Easwaran: The tamasic perform sacrifices ignoring both the letter and the spirit. They omit the proper prayers, the proper offerings, the proper food, and the proper faith.
Mahatma Gandhi: Sacrifice which is contrary to the rule, which produces no food, which lacks  the sacred text, which involves no giving up, which is devoid of faith is said to  be tamasa.
Shri Swami Purohit: Sacrifice that is contrary to scriptural command, that is unaccompanied by prayers or gifts of food or money, and is without faith – that is the product of Ignorance.

Eknath Easwaran: To offer service to the gods, to the good, to the wise, and to your spiritual teacher; purity, honesty, continence, and nonviolence: these are the disciplines of the body.
Mahatma Gandhi: Homage to the gods, to Brahmanas, to gurus and to wise men; cleanliness,  uprightness, brahmacharya and non-violence—these constitute austerity (tapas)  of the body.
Shri Swami Purohit: Worship of God and the Master; respect for the preacher and the philosopher; purity, rectitude, continence and harmlessness – all this is physical austerity.

Eknath Easwaran: To offer soothing words, to speak truly, kindly, and helpfully, and to study the scriptures: these are the disciplines of speech.
Mahatma Gandhi: Words that cause no hurt, that are true loving and helpful, and spiritual  study constitute austerity of speech.
Shri Swami Purohit: Speech that hurts no one, that is true, is pleasant to listen to and beneficial, and the constant study of the scriptures – this is austerity in speech.

Eknath Easwaran: Calmness, gentleness, silence, self-restraint, and purity: these are the disciplines of the mind.
Mahatma Gandhi: Serenity, benignity, silence, self-restraint, and purity of the spirit—these  constitute austerity of the mind.
Shri Swami Purohit: Serenity, kindness, silence, self-control and purity – this is austerity of mind.

Eknath Easwaran: When these three levels of self-discipline are practiced without attachment to the results, but in a spirit of great faith, the sages call this practice sattvic.
Mahatma Gandhi: This threefold austerity practiced in perfect faith by men not desirous of  fruit, and disciplined, is said to be sattvika.
Shri Swami Purohit: These threefold austerities performed with faith, and without thought of reward, may truly be accounted Pure.

Eknath Easwaran: Disciplines practiced in order to gain respect, honor, or admiration are rajasic; they are undependable and transitory in their effects.
Mahatma Gandhi: Austerity which is practiced with an eye to gain praise, honour and homage  and for ostentation is said to be rajasa; it is fleeting and unstable.
Shri Swami Purohit: Austerity coupled with hypocrisy or performed for the sake of self-glorification, popularity or vanity, comes from Passion, and its result is always doubtful and temporary.

Eknath Easwaran: Disciplines practiced to gain power over others, or in the confused belief that to torture oneself is spiritual, are tamasic.
Mahatma Gandhi: Austerity which is practiced from any foolish obsession, either to torture  oneself or to procure another's ruin, is called tamasa.
Shri Swami Purohit: Austerity done under delusion, and accompanied with sorcery or torture to oneself or another, may be assumed to spring from Ignorance.

Eknath Easwaran: Giving simply because it is right to give, without thought of return, at a proper time, in proper circumstances, and to a worthy person, is sattvic giving.
Mahatma Gandhi: Charity, given as a matter of duty, without expectation of any return, at the  right place and time, and to the right person is said to be sattvika.
Shri Swami Purohit: The gift which is given without thought of recompense, in the belief that it ought to be made, in a fit place, at an opportune time and to a deserving person – such a gift is Pure.

Eknath Easwaran: Giving with regrets or in the expectation of receiving some favor or of getting something in return is rajasic.
Mahatma Gandhi: Charity, which is given either in hope of receiving in return, or with a view  of winning merit, or grudgingly, is declared to be rajasa.
Shri Swami Purohit: That which is given for the sake of the results it will produce, or with the hope of recompense,or grudgingly – that may truly be said to be the outcome of Passion.

Eknath Easwaran: Giving at an inappropriate time, in inappropriate circumstances, and to an unworthy person, without affection or respect, is tamasic.
Mahatma Gandhi: Charity given at the wrong place and time, and to the undeserving recipient  disrespectfully and with contempt is declared to be tamasa.
Shri Swami Purohit: And that which is given at an unsuitable place or time or to one who is unworthy, or with disrespect or contempt – such a gift is the result of Ignorance.

Eknath Easwaran: Om Tat Sat: these three words represent Brahman, from which come priests and scriptures and sacrifice.
Mahatma Gandhi: AUM TAT SAT has been declared to be the threefold name of Brahman and  by that name were created of old the Brahmanas, the Vedas and sacrifices.
Shri Swami Purohit: `Om Tat Sat’ is the triple designation of the Eternal Spirit, by which of old the Vedic Scriptures, the ceremonials and the sacrifices were ordained.

Eknath Easwaran: Those who follow the Vedas, therefore, always repeat the word Om when offering sacrifices, performing spiritual disciplines, or giving gifts.
Mahatma Gandhi: Therefore, with AUM ever on their lips, are all the rites of sacrifice, charity  and austerity, performed always to the rule, by Brahmavadins.
Shri Swami Purohit: Therefore all acts of sacrifice, gifts and austerities, prescribed by the scriptures, are always begun by those who understand the Spirit with the word Om.

Eknath Easwaran: Those seeking liberation and not any personal benefit add the word Tat when performing these acts of worship, discipline, and charity.
Mahatma Gandhi: With the utterance of TAT and without the desire for fruit are the several  rites of sacrifice, austerity and charity performed by those seeking Freedom.
Shri Swami Purohit: Those who desire deliverance begin their acts of sacrifice, austerity or gift with the word `Tat’ (meaning `That’), without thought of reward.

Eknath Easwaran: Sat means that which is; it also indicates goodness. Therefore it is used to describe a worthy deed.
Mahatma Gandhi: SAT is employed in the sense of ‘real' and ‘good'; O Arjuna, SAT is also  applied to beautiful deeds.
Shri Swami Purohit: `Sat’ means Reality or the highest Good, and also, O Arjuna, it is used to mean an action of exceptional merit.

Eknath Easwaran: To be steadfast in self-sacrifice, self-discipline, and giving is sat. To act in accordance with these three is sat as well.
Mahatma Gandhi: Constancy in sacrifice, austerity and charity, is called SAT; and all work for  those purposes is also SAT.
Shri Swami Purohit: Conviction in sacrifice, in austerity and in giving is also called `Sat.’ So too an action done only for the Lord’s sake.

Eknath Easwaran: But to engage in sacrifice, self-discipline, and giving without good faith is asat, without worth or goodness, either in this life or in the next.
Mahatma Gandhi: Whatever is done, O Arjuna, by way of sacrifice, charity or austerity or any  other work, is called Asat if done without faith. It counts for nothing hereafter as  here.
Shri Swami Purohit: Whatsoever is done without faith, whether it be sacrifice, austerity or gift or anything else, as called `Asat’ (meaning `Unreal’) for it is the negation of `Sat,’ O Arjuna! Such an act has no significance, here or hereafter.”
